column1: Alameda ( AL-ə-MEE-də; Spanish: [ala'meða]) is a city in Alameda County
column3: United States. It spans Alameda Island and Bay Farm Island. It is adjacent to and south of Oakland and east of San Francisco across the San Francisco Bay. Bay Farm Island
column4: a portion of which is also known as "Harbor Bay Isle"
column5: is part of the mainland adjacent to Oakland International Airport. The city's estimated 2019 population was 77

column8: and adopted a council–manager government in 1916.

column1: Alameda occupies what was originally a peninsula connected to Oakland. Much of it was low-lying and marshy. The higher ground nearby and adjacent parts of what is now downtown Oakland were the site of one of the largest coastal oak forests in the world. Spanish colonists called the area Encinal
column2: meaning "forest of evergreen oak". Alameda is Spanish for "grove of poplar trees
column3: or tree-lined avenue." It was chosen as the name of the city in 1853 by popular vote.The inhabitants at the time of the arrival of the Spanish in the late 18th century were a local band of the Ohlone tribe. The peninsula was included in the vast Rancho San Antonio granted in 1820 to Luis Peralta by the Spanish king who claimed California. The grant was later confirmed by the Republic of Mexico upon its independence in 1821 from Spain.

column2: the place became known as Bolsa de Encinal or Encinal de San Antonio.

column1: The city was founded on June 6
column3: after the United States acquired California following the Mexican-American War of 1848. The town originally contained three small settlements. "Alameda" referred to the village at Encinal and High streets
column4: Hibbardsville was located at the North Shore ferry and shipping terminal
column5: and Woodstock was on the west near the ferry piers of the South Pacific Coast Railroad and the Central Pacific. Eventually
column6: the Central Pacific's ferry pier became the Alameda Mole
column7: featuring transit connections among the  San Francisco ferries
column8: local trollies
column9: and Southern Pacific (formerly Central Pacific) commuter lines.

column1: The first post office opened in 1854. The first school
column3: was opened in 1855 (and eventually was renamed as Lincoln School); Encinal School was opened in 1860 (and closed in 1980). The San Francisco and Alameda Railroad opened the Encinal station in 1864. The Encinal area was also known as Fasskings Station in honor of Frederick Louis Fassking. Encinal's own post office opened in 1876
column4: was renamed West End in 1877
column5: and closed in 1891. The West End area was originally called Bowman's Point in honor of Charles G. Bowman
column6: an early United States settler.On September 6
column8: the Alameda Terminal made history; it was the site of the arrival of the first train via the First Transcontinental Railroad to reach the shores of San Francisco Bay
column9: thus achieving the first coast to coast transcontinental railroad in North America. The transcontinental terminus was switched to the Oakland Pier two months later

column1: The borders of Alameda were made coextensive with the island in 1872
column2: incorporating Woodstock into Alameda. In his autobiography
column3: writer Mark Twain described Alameda as "The Garden of California."

column2: a private entertainment park called Neptune Beach was built in the area now known as Crab Cove. Often compared to Coney Island in Brooklyn
column3: New York
column4: the park was a major recreation destination in the 1920s and 1930s. The original owners
column6: partnered with a local confectioner to create treats unique to Neptune Beach. Both the American snow cone and the popsicle were first sold at Neptune Beach. The Kewpie doll
column7: hand-painted and dressed in unique hand-sewn dresses
column8: became the original prize for winning games of chance at the beach – another Neptune Beach innovation. The Strehlows owned and operated the beach on their own. They filled in a section of the bay to add an additional Olympic-size swimming pool and a roller coaster
column9: which must have given riders a tremendous view of the bay. The Cottage Baths were available for rent.

column1: Neptune Beach's two large outdoor pools hosted swimming races and exhibitions by such notable swimmers such as Olympian Johnny Weissmuller and Jack LaLanne. Weissmuller later starred in films as the original Tarzan character. LaLanne started a longlasting chain of health clubs and appeared on television. The park closed down in 1939 because the Great Depression left many people without much money
column2: the completion of the San Francisco–Oakland Bay Bridge changed traffic patterns
column3: people avoided paying the admission price
column4: and the rise of car culture gave people many more choices for recreation destinations.

column1: Once the Bay Bridge was complete
column3: which ran past the entrance to Neptune Beach on the way to the Alameda Mole and the Ferry
column4: lost passengers in great number as people shifted to automobiles. People began using their cars to escape the city and the close suburbs like Alameda and traveled further afield in California. More distant locations appealed to cash-rich San Francisco tourists in the postwar years. Youngsters in town became aware of ways to avoid paying the dime for admission to the park. Strong swimmers or waders could sneak in on the bayside just by swimming around the fence.

column1: When the railroad came to town in 1860s
column2: Park Street developed as the major thoroughfare of the city. After the main Alameda train station was located here
column3: residents of Old Alameda pulled up stakes and moved across town to the new downtown. The street's location was chosen by two landowners who wished to attract tenants and development to their land. They designated their mutual property line as Park Street.

column1: The need for expanded shipping facilities and increased flow of current through the estuary led to the dredging of a tidal canal through the marshland between Oakland and Alameda. Construction started in 1874
column2: but it was not completed until 1902
column3: resulting in Alameda becoming an island.Most of the soil from the canal dredging was used to fill in the nearby marshland. The area of Alameda called Bay Farm Island is no longer an island but is attached by fill to Oakland. In his youth
column4: author Jack London was known to take part in oyster pirating in the highly productive oyster beds near Bay Farm Island

column1: Alameda's nickname is "The Island City" (or simply "the island"). The current city occupies two islands as well as a small section of the mainland. Today
column2: the city consists of the main original section

The Southshore area is separated from the main part of Alameda Island by a lagoon; the north shore of the lagoon is located approximately where the original south shore of the island was. Alameda Point and Southshore are built on bay fill.
